articles.headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis Casts a Shadow Over China
articles.snippet: The euro’s fall is hurting Chinese exports to Europe and making it harder to break its currency’s peg to the dollar.
articles.abstract: The euro’s fall is hurting Chinese exports to Europe and making it harder to break its currency’s peg to the dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The pain of the European debt crisis is spreading as the plummeting euro makes Chinese companies less competitive in Europe, their largest market, and complicates any move to break the Chinese currency’s peg to the dollar.

articles.headline: Justices Limit Life Sentences for Juveniles
articles.snippet: The ruling forbids sentences of life without parole for juveniles who do not participate in homicides.
articles.abstract: The ruling forbids sentences of life without parole for juveniles who do not participate in homicides.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that juveniles who commit crimes in which no one is killed may not be sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

articles.headline: Review Cites Flaws in U.S. Antimissile Program
articles.snippet: An analysis by two antimissile critics casts doubt on the reliability of a key part of U.S. defense strategy.
articles.abstract: An analysis by two antimissile critics casts doubt on the reliability of a key part of U.S. defense strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s plans for reducing America’s nuclear arsenal and defeating Iran’s missiles rely heavily on a new generation of antimissile defenses, which last year he called “proven and effective.”
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Senate Votes for a Clear Credit Score
articles.snippet: Under the amendment, the credit score would be provided if it is used to deny credit, require a higher interest rate on a loan, or prevent an applicant from being hired for a job.
articles.abstract: Under the amendment, the credit score would be provided if it is used to deny credit, require a higher interest rate on a loan, or prevent an applicant from being hired for a job.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anyone rejected for a credit card, car loan or department store charge account has most likely discovered a frustrating aspect of the government-mandated, free credit reports: the glaring absence of the numerical credit score that lenders rely on to make their decisions.

articles.headline: As Attention Wanders, Rethinking the Autopilot
articles.snippet: Recent examples of inattentiveness by pilots are raising questions among federal safety officials.
articles.abstract: Recent examples of inattentiveness by pilots are raising questions among federal safety officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: A captain returned to the cockpit after taking a bathroom break and found the first officer facing away from the instruments and talking to a flight attendant. Unnoticed was the fact that the autopilot had disconnected and the plane was in danger of stalling.

articles.headline: Bobbing as the Taxman Weaves
articles.snippet: Private equity and hedge fund firms are hard at work figuring out ways around new income tax laws they face.
articles.abstract: Private equity and hedge fund firms are hard at work figuring out ways around new income tax laws they face.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the long list of new financial regulations that were once considered improbable but now seem possible, add this one: a tax rule that would treat the investment gains of partners in hedge funds and private equity firms as ordinary income rather than as capital gains.

articles.headline: Russian Journalists, Fighting Graft, Pay in Blood
articles.snippet: Journalists and activists are being battered in a wave of unsolved attacks, a violent deterrent to those who question authority.
articles.abstract: Journalists and activists are being battered in a wave of unsolved attacks, a violent deterrent to those who question authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHIMKI, Russia — Mikhail Beketov had been warned, but would not stop writing. About dubious land deals. Crooked loans. Under-the-table hush money. All evidence, he argued in his newspaper, of rampant corruption in this Moscow suburb.

articles.headline: Taliban Car Bomb Strikes U.S. Convoy in Kabul
articles.snippet: The rush-hour attack killed 18 people, including 5 American soldiers and a Canadian officer, and wounded at least 47 civilians.
articles.abstract: The rush-hour attack killed 18 people, including 5 American soldiers and a Canadian officer, and wounded at least 47 civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban struck here at the heart of the Afghan capital Tuesday, with a suicide bomber steering his explosives-laden Toyota minibus into an American convoy as it moved through the thick of rush-hour traffic. The attack killed 18 people, including 5 American soldiers and an officer from Canada, and wounded at least 47 civilians.

articles.headline: Major Powers Have Deal on Sanctions for Iran
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Russia and China agreed to a deal a day after Iran made an offer to ship nuclear fuel.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Russia and China agreed to a deal a day after Iran made an offer to ship nuclear fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced an agreement on Tuesday with other major powers, including Russia and China, to impose a fourth set of sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program, setting the stage for an intense tug of war with Tehran as it tries to avoid passage of the penalties by the full United Nations Security Council.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Mark Landler
